page.title: 03Farming.N.Runcton,Middleton
page.content: Most of the work is now carried out by{machines}and ever increasing use is made of chemical fertilisers and sprays. Retired farm-workers who had worked all their lives on the land told us that the greatest change they had seen was the replacement of horses by{tractors}and the use of machines to replace hand methods. An important result of mechanisation is the decline of the{labour force}on the farms. One farmer told us he farms 200 acres single-handed, yet as recently as l5 years ago he employed six men full-time. Mechanisation and the smaller labour force has led to the widespread destruction of{hedgerows}here as elsewhere in East Anglia. Many hedgerows however remain. The same farmer told us that he had not removed any hedgerows in the last l5 years.
